title.text: A Graph-based Readability Assessment Method using Word Coupling

abstractContent.text: This paper proposes a graph-based read-ability assessment method using word coupling.

Compared to the state-of-the-art methods such as the readability for-mulae, the word-based and feature-based methods, our method develops a coupled bag-of-words model which combines the merits of word frequencies and text features.
Unlike the general bag-of-words model which assumes words are independent , our model correlates the words based on their similarities on readability.

By applying TF-IDF (Term Frequency and Inverse Document Frequency), the coupled TF-IDF matrix is built, and used in the graph-based classification framework, which involves graph building, merging and label propagation.
Experiments are conducted on both English and Chinese datasets.
The results demonstrate both effectiveness and potential of the method.

introductionContent.text: Readability assessment is a task that aims to evaluate the reading difficulty or comprehending easiness of text documents.

It is helpful for educationists to select texts appropriate to the reading/grade levels of the students, and for web designers to organize texts on web pages for the users doing personalized searches for information retrieval.
Research on readability assessment starts from the early 20th century ().
Many useful readability formulae have been developed since then ().
Currently, due to the development of natural language processing, the methods on readability assessment have made a great progress; * Corresponding author.).
The word-based methods compute word frequencies in documents to estimate their readability).
The feature-based methods extract text features from documents and train classification models to classify the readability (.
In this paper, we propose a graph-based method using word coupling, which combines the merits of both word frequencies and text features for readability assessment.
We design a coupled bag-of-words model, which correlates words based on their similarities on sentence-level readability computed using text features.
The model is used in a graph-based classification framework, which involves graph building, graph merging/combination, and label propagation.
We perform experiments on datasets of both English and Chinese.
The results demonstrate both effectiveness and potential of our method.
The rest of this paper is organized as follows: Section 2 introduces backgrounds of our work.
Section 3 presents the details of the method.
Section 4 designs the experiments and explains the results.
Finally, Section 5 concludes the paper with planned future work.
